xxl.core.io.converters

Class MeasuredTupleConverter

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.io.converters.Converter<T>
      • xxl.core.io.converters.MeasuredConverter<Tuple>
        • xxl.core.io.converters.MeasuredTupleConverter
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable

    public final class MeasuredTupleConverter
extends MeasuredConverter<Tuple>
    This class provides a converter which is able to read and write objects of type Tuple which contains a set of individual typed objects. Therefore the MeasuredTupleConverter calls the specific built-in XXL converter to read an write the single objects (components) of the tuple. First the converter reads or writes the length of the array. Thereafter the objects are read or written.

    Note: For various reasons, a tuple contains different typed objects but does not know its own column types. Therefore, a MeasuredTupleConverter expects an object that implements ResultSetMetaData. This provides the information about which types the tuple uses in its columns.

    Caution: The MeasuredTupleConverter auto matches Java types and relational types, e.g. VARCHAR and LONGNVARCHAR to java.lang.String using Convert.toJavaTyp() and vice versa using Convert.toRelationalType(). Please note that every type is matched currently but not every relational type can be written or read at this point. If you use e.g. CLOB (JDBC) type the MeasuredTupleConverter will throw an UnsupportedOperationException.

    Actually you can write and read the following types
    • java BOOLEAN and jdbc BOOLEAN
    • java BYTE and jdbc TINYINT, BOOLEAN
    • java DATE and jdbc DATE
    • java DOUBLE and jdbc DOUBLE
    • java FLOAT and jdbc REAL
    • java INT and jdbc INTEGER
    • java LONG and jdbc BIGINT
    • java SHORT and jdbc SMALLINT
    • java STRING and jdbc CHAR, LONGNVARCHAR, LONGVARCHAR, NCHAR, NVARCHAR, VARCHAR
    • java TIME and jdbc TIME
    • java TIMESTAMP and jdbc TIMESTAMP


        • Example of MeasuredTupleConverter writing

        The following example shows how to create tuples in a table TABLE_NAME and how to store them into a file called dumpFile. Each tuple contains two columns. The first is an INTEGER (JDBC type) and the second is a VARCHAR (JDCBC type). The example uses ColumnMetaInfo which is designed for quick using RelationalType. Instead of this you can also use ColumnMetaData. After adding some tuples with values the example code writes sequentially each tuple content to dumpFile. 
                File dumpFile = new File(DUMP_FILE_PATH);
                                                
        FileOutputStream fileOutputStream = new FileOutputStream(dumpFile);
        DataOutputStream dataOutputStream = new DataOutputStream(fileOutputStream);
        final String TABLE_NAME = "Students";
 
        ColumnMetaInfo columnMetaData[] = new ColumnMetaInfo[] {  
                        new ColumnMetaInfo(RelationalType.INTEGER, "MatrNr", TABLE_NAME),
                        new ColumnMetaInfo(RelationalType.VARCHAR, "Name", TABLE_NAME) };
 
        ColumnMetaDataResultSetMetaData metaData = new ColumnMetaDataResultSetMetaData(columnMetaData);
                        MeasuredTupleConverter tc = new MeasuredTupleConverter(metaData);
 
        ArrayTuple tupleArray[] = new ArrayTuple[] { 
                        new ArrayTuple(new Integer(23), new String("Mustermann")),
                        new ArrayTuple(new Integer(24), new String("Musterfrau")),
                        new ArrayTuple(new Integer(25), new String("Doe"))  }; 
 
        for (Tuple t : tupleArray) 
                        tc.write(dataOutputStream, t);


        Example of MeasuredTupleConverter reading

        The following example shows how to restore tuples from a previous session from a file called dumpFile. Each tuple contains two columns. The first is an INTEGER (JDBC type) and the second is a VARCHAR (JDCBC type). Please make sure that the schema for the new tuple is exactly the same as the schema of the written previously (as it is in this example code). The example uses ColumnMetaInfo which is designed for quick using RelationalType. Instead of this you can also use ColumnMetaData. After setup this, the MeasuredTupleConverter reads the first tuple from dumpFile and restore it into a new object tuple. You can load all tuples by calling read(DataInput) sequentially. 
         FileInputStream fileInputStream = new FileInputStream(new File("files/tupleDump.tmp"));
 DataInputStream dataInputStream = new DataInputStream(fileInputStream);
 final String TABLE_NAME = "Students";
 
 ColumnMetaInfo columnMetaData[] = new ColumnMetaInfo[] { 
                new ColumnMetaInfo(RelationalType.INTEGER, "MatNr", TABLE_NAME), 
                new ColumnMetaInfo(RelationalType.VARCHAR, "Name", TABLE_NAME) };
 
 ColumnMetaDataResultSetMetaData metaData = new ColumnMetaDataResultSetMetaData(columnMetaData);
 MeasuredTupleConverter tc = new MeasuredTupleConverter(metaData);
 
 Tuple readedTuple = tc.read(dataInputStream);
    See Also:
    ColumnMetaData, ColumnMetaInfo, RelationalType, JavaType, ConvertUtils, Tuple, Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • MeasuredTupleConverter

        public MeasuredTupleConverter(ExtendedResultSetMetaData tupleMetaData)
        Creates a new converter for objects of type Tuple. A tuple includes a lot of different typed objects. Since a tuple does not know his own object types a description of the data type of the contained objects will be needed here.
        Note: Please check that meta data and tuples match in their object size (dimension)
        Parameters:
        tupleMetaData - A type description of the contained objects within your tuples. You can use objects which implements ResultSetMetaData
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if tupleMetaData is null

    • Method Detail

      • getMaxObjectSize

        public int getMaxObjectSize()
        Get the maximum size by the sum of all single sizes of all columns.
        Specified by:
        getMaxObjectSize in class MeasuredConverter<Tuple>
        Returns:
        the maximal size of the objects for which this converter is used.

      • read

        public Tuple read(DataInput dataInput,
                  Tuple t)
           throws IOException
        Restores a tuple from an input. This read based on the meta data information given in constructor.
        Note: Please check that meta data and tuples match in their object size (dimension)
        Specified by:
        read in class Converter<Tuple>
        Parameters:
        dataInput - the input from which the tuple should be loaded

        _ - ignore this argument, it's unused
        Returns:
        The restored tuple with the schema you defined in the constructor
        Throws:
        IOException - if it fails to read from dataInput RuntimeException if tuple dimension and meta data dimension does not match SQLException if a SQLException occurs within your ResultSetMetaData

      • readWithType

        public Object readWithType(DataInput dataInput,
                           int columnType,
                           int columnIndex)
        Reads a date from the dataInput. The metadata about the types of the individual components of the tuples is known while constructing this TupleConverter. This method takes a relational data type, translates it into a Java language type and reads an object of this type from the input. The read object is then returned.

        For type converting, see JDBC Types
        Parameters:
        dataInput - The input from which a date should be read
        columnType - The relational type of the object which should be read
        Returns:
        The (according to the translation between Java language and relational language) typed into Object casted date.

      • write

        public void write(DataOutput dataOutput,
                  Tuple singleTuple)
           throws IOException
        Stores a tuple sequentially into dataOutput. This writing operations needs info about each column type which you set in constructor of MeasuredTupleConverter.
        Note: Please check that meta data and tuples match in their object size (dimension)
        Specified by:
        write in class Converter<Tuple>
        Parameters:
        dataOutput - the stream to write the state (the attributes) of the object to.
        singleTuple - the object whose state (attributes) should be written to the data output.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if singleTuple is null IOException if it fails to write into dataOutput RuntimeException if tuple dimension and meta data dimension does not match SQLException if a SQLException occurs within your ResultSetMetaData
        IOException - includes any I/O exceptions that may occur.

      • writeWithType

        public void writeWithType(DataOutput dataOutput,
                          Tuple tuple,
                          int columnIndex,
                          int columnType)
        Writes the value of the given column index into dataOutput. For this purpose, the type of the column type is determined with the given MetaData and written with the specific XXL converter for this type.

        For type converting, see JDBC Types
        Parameters:
        dataOutput - The output in which the object at columnIndex of tuple should be written
        tuple - The tuple object
        columnIndex - The index of the tuples item which should be written into dataOutput
